laws.summary: Oregon restricts non-compete agreements significantly. O.R.S. § 653.295 prohibits non-competes for employees earning less than $123,428/year (2026 threshold, adjusted biennially). For higher earners, non-competes limited to 12 months maximum. Healthcare practitioners (physicians, NPs, PAs, etc.) are prohibited from non-competes entirely as of July 1, 2025.
requirements: WAGE THRESHOLD: Cannot enforce non-compete for employees earning less than $123,428/year (2026 threshold, adjusted every 2 years based on median family income)
For employees above threshold: Non-compete limited to 12 months maximum
Must provide written notice of non-compete at job offer or 2 weeks before start of employment
Must be in writing
Geographic scope must be reasonable
HEALTHCARE PRACTITIONERS: Non-competes PROHIBITED for physicians, nurse practitioners, physician assistants, optometrists, dentists, dental hygienists (effective July 1, 2025)
HEALTHCARE: Exception for sale of practice
Non-solicitation agreements: More lenient - can enforce for employees earning $103,690+ (2026 threshold)
Customer non-solicitation: Maximum 18 months
Employee must receive bona fide advancement (promotion, salary increase, or other consideration) for existing employee non-compete
Courts will NOT blue-pencil unreasonable provisions
Void non-competes: Employer may be liable for attorney fees
laws.notes: Oregon significantly restricts non-competes. Healthcare practitioner ban took effect July 2025. Wage thresholds adjusted biennially. Federal FTC ban blocked but Oregon law already restrictive.

laws.summary: Oregon prohibits employers from asking about salary history. O.R.S. § 652.220 prevents employers from screening applicants based on salary history or requiring disclosure of current/past compensation. One of the early adopter states.
requirements: Employers cannot screen applicants based on current or past compensation
Cannot require disclosure of salary history as condition of employment
Cannot require disclosure as condition for being interviewed
Cannot determine whether to interview based on salary history
Applicant may voluntarily disclose salary history without prompting
If voluntarily disclosed, employer may verify and consider
Does not prohibit asking about salary expectations
Applies to all Oregon employers
Violations: Civil penalties enforced by Commissioner of Bureau of Labor and Industries (BOLI)
Effective October 6, 2017
laws.notes: Oregon was one of first states to ban salary history inquiries. Part of broader pay equity law.

laws.summary: Oregon requires pay transparency. O.R.S. § 652.210 requires employers with 15+ employees to include salary range or wage scale in job postings. Must also provide pay scale information to current employees upon request or hire/transfer/promotion.
requirements: Applies to employers with 15 or more employees
Must include salary range or wage scale in ALL job postings for positions in Oregon
Posting must show: minimum and maximum salary/wage for position
Must include general description of benefits and other compensation
Applies to: external job postings, internal postings, transfer opportunities, promotional opportunities
Includes remote positions if work performed in Oregon
Must provide wage scale information to employees: upon hire, upon transfer to new position, upon promotion, at any time upon request
Cannot retaliate against employees who discuss wages
Cannot prohibit employees from disclosing their own wages
Violations: Enforced by Oregon Bureau of Labor and Industries (BOLI), civil penalties
Effective January 1, 2025
laws.notes: Oregon pay transparency law took effect January 2025. Applies to employers with 15+ employees.

laws.summary: Oregon has comprehensive ban-the-box law. O.R.S. § 659A.360 prohibits employers from asking about criminal history on initial applications or before initial interview. Must conduct individualized assessment. Cannot consider arrests more than 3 years old without conviction.
laws.statute_citation: O.R.S. § 659A.360 (Criminal History in Employment); Federal FCRA (15 U.S.C. § 1681)
requirements: Cannot ask about criminal history on initial employment application
Cannot ask about criminal history before initial interview
Cannot conduct background check before initial interview
After initial interview: May inquire about criminal history and conduct background check
Cannot consider: arrests not resulting in conviction (if more than 3 years old), expunged/sealed records, juvenile records
Must conduct individualized assessment before taking adverse action
Must consider: nature/gravity of offense, time elapsed, nature of job sought, evidence of rehabilitation
Must provide written notice before adverse action
Applicant has 5 business days to respond with evidence of inaccuracy or rehabilitation
Exceptions: Positions where law prohibits hiring with certain convictions
FCRA: Must get written consent for background check
FCRA: Must provide pre-adverse action and final adverse action notices
Violations: Enforced by Oregon Bureau of Labor and Industries (BOLI)
Civil penalties: Up to $1,000 per violation
laws.notes: Oregon has strong ban-the-box protections. Cannot ask about criminal history until after initial interview. Must conduct individualized assessment.

laws.summary: Oregon has comprehensive paid sick leave law. O.R.S. § 653.601 et seq. requires all employers to provide earned sick time. Employees accrue minimum 1 hour per 30 hours worked (or 1 hour per 40 for employers with 10+ employees in Portland metro). Oregon also has Paid Leave Oregon program for family/medical leave starting September 2023.
laws.statute_citation: O.R.S. § 653.601 et seq. (Paid Sick Leave); O.R.S. § 657B.010 et seq. (Paid Leave Oregon)
requirements: PAID SICK LEAVE: Applies to ALL Oregon employers regardless of size
PAID SICK LEAVE: Employees accrue minimum 1 hour per 30 hours worked
PAID SICK LEAVE: Employers with 10+ employees (or 6+ in Portland metro): paid sick time
PAID SICK LEAVE: Smaller employers: unpaid sick time
PAID SICK LEAVE: Maximum 40 hours per year
PAID SICK LEAVE: Can use after 91st calendar day of employment
PAID SICK LEAVE: Carries over year to year (employer may cap accrual at 80 hours)
PAID SICK LEAVE: Use for: illness/injury, medical care, public health emergency, child's illness/care, domestic violence/harassment/sexual assault/stalking situations, bereavement
PAID SICK LEAVE: NOT required to pay out at termination
PAID LEAVE OREGON: State-run program provides up to 12 weeks paid leave (14 for pregnancy disability, 16 combined)
PAID LEAVE OREGON: Covers: serious health condition, family care, bonding with child, safe leave
PAID LEAVE OREGON: Funded by payroll contributions (employer + employee)
PAID LEAVE OREGON: Applies to employees who worked 120 days in Oregon
PAID LEAVE OREGON: Started September 3, 2023
Records must be maintained for 3 years
Retaliation prohibited
laws.effective_date: Paid sick leave: 2016-01-01; Paid Leave Oregon: 2023-09-03
laws.notes: Oregon has comprehensive paid leave system. State-run Paid Leave Oregon provides family/medical leave benefits. Separate paid sick leave law for all employers.

laws.summary: Oregon enforces arbitration agreements under federal and state law but with employee protections. Follows Federal Arbitration Act. Oregon Uniform Arbitration Act governs. Courts scrutinize for fairness and may find unconscionable if one-sided.
laws.statute_citation: Federal Arbitration Act (9 U.S.C. §§ 1-16); O.R.S. § 36.600 et seq. (Uniform Arbitration Act)
requirements: Arbitration agreements generally enforceable under FAA
Must be in writing and clearly presented
Must have mutual agreement to arbitrate
Must identify claims subject to arbitration
Cannot be procedurally or substantively unconscionable
Must provide for neutral arbitrator
Cannot impose unreasonable costs on employee
Adequate consideration required
Oregon courts scrutinize arbitration agreements for fairness
Class action waivers generally enforceable but may be challenged
Pre-dispute arbitration agreements enforceable if fair
Can be challenged on unconscionability grounds
Federal policy favoring arbitration applies but state law provides protections
laws.effective_date: Ongoing under federal and state law
laws.notes: Oregon enforces arbitration but with employee-friendly scrutiny. Must be procedurally fair.

laws.summary: Oregon follows at-will employment doctrine with significant exceptions. Either party can terminate employment for any legal reason. Strong anti-discrimination protections, whistleblower protections, and public policy exceptions. Oregon is moderately employee-friendly.
laws.statute_citation: Common law doctrine; O.R.S. § 659A.030 (Oregon Equality Act - anti-discrimination)
requirements: Default: Employment terminable at will by either party
No notice required unless contract/policy requires it
Final wages: If employee quits with 48+ hours notice, must pay immediately; if less notice, within 5 days or next payday, whichever comes first; if terminated, must pay by end of next business day

EXCEPTIONS - Cannot terminate for: Race, color, religion, sex, sexual orientation, gender identity, national origin, marital status, age 18+, disability, source of income, domestic violence victim status, familial status, expunged juvenile record (Oregon Equality Act - very broad)
Cannot terminate for: Retaliation (whistleblowing, workers' comp, wage claims, jury duty, military service, victim of crime assistance)
Cannot terminate for: Serving as volunteer firefighter/emergency responder
Cannot terminate for: Off-duty legal marijuana use (with exceptions for safety-sensitive positions)
Cannot terminate for: Violation of public policy
Cannot terminate for: Breach of employment contract
Employment handbooks may create enforceable obligations if not properly disclaimed
Written employment contracts override at-will status
Union/collective bargaining agreements override at-will status
laws.notes: Oregon has strong employee protections including broad anti-discrimination law and marijuana protections. Handbook disclaimers important.

laws.summary: Oregon restricts drug testing, particularly for marijuana. O.R.S. § 659A.300 prohibits employment discrimination for off-duty marijuana use. Employers must have reasonable suspicion of impairment. Pre-employment marijuana testing significantly limited. Safety-sensitive positions have more latitude.
laws.statute_citation: O.R.S. § 659A.300 et seq. (Marijuana Use); O.R.S. § 659A.300 (Drug/Alcohol Testing)
requirements: Cannot discriminate based on off-duty marijuana use (with exceptions)
Pre-employment marijuana testing: Prohibited for most positions (as of 2024)
Cannot refuse to hire solely based on pre-employment marijuana test

EXCEPTIONS: Can test and take action for: safety-sensitive positions, positions requiring federal background checks/contracts/licensing, positions with potential adverse impact on safety of others, positions where impairment could create unacceptable risk
Random testing: Only permitted for safety-sensitive positions
Reasonable suspicion testing: Permitted if observable evidence of impairment
Post-accident testing: Permitted
Must have written drug testing policy
Policy must be provided to employees/applicants
Testing must be conducted by qualified lab
Cannot test based solely on smell of marijuana
Must establish observable impairment, not just positive test
Medical marijuana: Same protections as recreational
Federal contractors: Must comply with Drug-Free Workplace Act
DOT-regulated positions: Must follow federal testing requirements
Workers' comp: Drug testing provisions may affect claims
laws.notes: Oregon has strong marijuana employee protections. Pre-employment marijuana testing largely prohibited. Cannot discriminate for off-duty use unless safety-sensitive. Must show impairment, not just use.

data_quality.sources: Oregon statutes (O.R.S.), Oregon Bureau of Labor and Industries (BOLI), legal analysis

additional_notes.general_guidance: Oregon is VERY employee-friendly with comprehensive worker protections. Strong non-compete restrictions (including healthcare ban), pay transparency, paid sick leave, state-run paid family leave, marijuana protections, and broad anti-discrimination law create significant compliance requirements.
enforcement_agencies: Oregon Bureau of Labor and Industries (BOLI)
recent_developments: Healthcare practitioner non-compete ban effective July 1, 2025
One of most comprehensive employment law states in U.S.
